using LearnEF.Models;
using System;
using System.Collections.Generic;
using System.Linq;
using System.Text;
using System.Threading.Tasks;

namespace LearnEF.Repositories
{
    internal class ProductRepository : IProductRepository
    {
        private readonly AppDbContext _context;
        public ProductRepository(AppDbContext context)
        {
            _context = context;
        }
        public void Add(Product product) {
            _context.Products.Add(product);
            _context.SaveChanges();
        }
        public void Update(Product product) {
            _context.Products.Update(product);
            _context.SaveChanges();
        }
        public Product? GetByName(string name)
        {
            return _context.Products.FirstOrDefault(p => p.Name == name);
        }
        public void Delete(Product product) {
            _context.Products.Remove(product);
            _context.SaveChanges();
        }
        public IEnumerable<Product> GetAll() {
            return _context.Products;
        }
    }
}

docs.title: Program.cs
docs.text:
using LearnEF.Models;
using LearnEF.Repositories;

class Program
{
    static void Main(string[] args)
    {
        using (var context = new AppDbContext())
        {
            var repo = new ProductRepository(context);

            while (true)
            {
                Console.WriteLine("\n=== PRODUCT MENU ===");
                Console.WriteLine("1. Read Data");
                Console.WriteLine("2. Insert Data");
                Console.WriteLine("3. Update Data");
                Console.WriteLine("4. Delete Data");
                Console.WriteLine("5. Get By Name");
                Console.WriteLine("0. Exit");
                Console.Write("Choose menu: ");

                var choice = Console.ReadLine();

                switch (choice)
                {
                    case "1": // READ
                        var products = repo.GetAll();
                        Console.WriteLine("\n--- Product Data ---");
                        foreach (var p in products)
                            Console.WriteLine($"{p.Id} | {p.Name} - {p.Price}");
                        break;

                    case "2": // INSERT
                        Console.Write("Product Name: ");
                        string name = Console.ReadLine() ?? "";

                        Console.Write("Product Price: ");
                        decimal price;
                        decimal.TryParse(Console.ReadLine(), out price);

                        var newProduct = new Product { Name = name, Price = price };
                        repo.Add(newProduct);
                        Console.WriteLine("Product added successfully.");
                        break;

                    case "3": // UPDATE
                        Console.Write("Enter product name to update: ");
                        string updateName = Console.ReadLine() ?? "";
                        var existing = repo.GetByName(updateName);

                        if (existing != null)
                        {
                            Console.Write("New Price: ");
                            decimal newPrice;
                            decimal.TryParse(Console.ReadLine(), out newPrice);

                            existing.Price = newPrice;
                            repo.Update(existing);
                            Console.WriteLine("Product updated successfully.");
                        }
                        else
                        {
                            Console.WriteLine("Product not found.");
                        }
                        break;

                    case "4": // DELETE
                        Console.Write("Enter product name to delete: ");
                        string deleteName = Console.ReadLine() ?? "";
                        var toDelete = repo.GetByName(deleteName);

                        if (toDelete != null)
                        {
                            repo.Delete(toDelete);
                            Console.WriteLine("Product deleted successfully.");
                        }
                        else
                        {
                            Console.WriteLine("Product not found.");
                        }
                        break;

                    case "5": // GET BY NAME
                        Console.Write("Enter product name: ");
                        string searchName = Console.ReadLine() ?? "";
                        var product = repo.GetByName(searchName);

                        if (product != null)
                        {
                            Console.WriteLine($"Found: {product.Id} | {product.Name} - {product.Price}");
                        }
                        else
                        {
                            Console.WriteLine("Product not found.");
                        }
                        break;

                    case "0": // EXIT
                        Console.WriteLine("Exiting program...");
                        return;

                    default:
                        Console.WriteLine("Invalid choice.");
                        break;
                }
            }
        }
    }
}

docs.title: .NET Environment Variables
docs.text: Configuring behavior in .NET applications using environment variables, often used in conjunction with appsettings.json.

docs.title: Configuration Provider
docs.text:
By default, .NET loads environment variables via the EnvironmentVariablesConfigurationProvider.

// Program.cs
var builder = WebApplication.CreateBuilder(args);
// Builder automatically calls AddEnvironmentVariables()

docs.title: Naming Conventions
docs.text: To map nested JSON configuration to environment variables, use double underscores (__). ConnectionStrings:DefaultConnection becomes ConnectionStrings__DefaultConnection.

docs.title: Accessing Variables

// Via IConfiguration (Preferred)
string dbHost = configuration["DB_HOST"];

// Directly from the system
string path = Environment.GetEnvironmentVariable("PATH");

// Calculator.cs
namespace MyLibrary
{
    public class Calculator
    {
        public int Add(int a, int b)
        {
            return a + b;
        }

        public int Subtract(int a, int b)
        {
            return a - b;
        }

        public int Multiply(int a, int b)
        {
            return a * b;
        }

        public double Divide(int a, int b)
        {
            if (b == 0)
                throw new ArgumentException("Cannot divide by zero", nameof(b));

            return (double)a / b;
        }

        public double GetCircleArea(double radius)
        {
            if (radius < 0)
                throw new ArgumentException("Radius cannot be negative", nameof(radius));

            return Math.PI * radius * radius;
        }
    }
}

docs.title: Step 3: Create a Person Class

// Person.cs
namespace MyLibrary
{
    public class Person
    {
        public string FirstName { get; set; } = string.Empty;
        public string LastName { get; set; } = string.Empty;
        public DateTime BirthDate { get; set; }

        public string FullName => $"{FirstName} {LastName}";

        public int Age
        {
            get
            {
                var today = DateTime.Today;
                var age = today.Year - BirthDate.Year;

                if (BirthDate.Date > today.AddYears(-age))
                    age--;

                return age;
            }
        }

        public bool IsAdult => Age >= 18;

        public Person(string firstName, string lastName, DateTime birthDate)
        {
            FirstName = firstName;
            LastName = lastName;
            BirthDate = birthDate;
        }

        public override string ToString()
        {
            return $"{FullName} (Age: {Age})";
        }
    }
}

// CalculatorApp/Program.cs
using MyLibrary;

Console.WriteLine("=== Simple Calculator ===");
Console.WriteLine();

var calculator = new Calculator();
bool continueCalculation = true;

while (continueCalculation)
{
    try
    {
        Console.WriteLine("Choose an operation:");
        Console.WriteLine("1. Addition");
        Console.WriteLine("2. Subtraction");
        Console.WriteLine("3. Multiplication");
        Console.WriteLine("4. Division");
        Console.WriteLine("5. Circle Area");
        Console.WriteLine("6. Exit");
        Console.Write("Enter your choice (1-6): ");

        string? choice = Console.ReadLine();

        switch (choice)
        {
            case "1":
                PerformBasicOperation(calculator.Add, "Addition");
                break;
            case "2":
                PerformBasicOperation(calculator.Subtract, "Subtraction");
                break;
            case "3":
                PerformBasicOperation(calculator.Multiply, "Multiplication");
                break;
            case "4":
                PerformDivision(calculator);
                break;
            case "5":
                CalculateCircleArea(calculator);
                break;
            case "6":
                continueCalculation = false;
                Console.WriteLine("Thank you for using the calculator!");
                break;
            default:
                Console.WriteLine("Invalid choice. Please try again.");
                break;
        }

        if (continueCalculation)
        {
            Console.WriteLine();
            Console.WriteLine("Press any key to continue...");
            Console.ReadKey();
            Console.Clear();
        }
    }
    catch (Exception ex)
    {
        Console.WriteLine($"An error occurred: {ex.Message}");
        Console.WriteLine();
    }
}

static void PerformBasicOperation(Func<int, int, int> operation, string operationName)
{
    Console.Write("Enter first number: ");
    if (int.TryParse(Console.ReadLine(), out int num1))
    {
        Console.Write("Enter second number: ");
        if (int.TryParse(Console.ReadLine(), out int num2))
        {
            int result = operation(num1, num2);
            Console.WriteLine($"{operationName} result: {result}");
        }
        else
        {
            Console.WriteLine("Invalid second number.");
        }
    }
    else
    {
        Console.WriteLine("Invalid first number.");
    }
}

static void PerformDivision(Calculator calculator)
{
    Console.Write("Enter first number: ");
    if (int.TryParse(Console.ReadLine(), out int num1))
    {
        Console.Write("Enter second number: ");
        if (int.TryParse(Console.ReadLine(), out int num2))
        {
            try
            {
                double result = calculator.Divide(num1, num2);
                Console.WriteLine($"Division result: {result:F2}");
            }
            catch (ArgumentException ex)
            {
                Console.WriteLine($"Error: {ex.Message}");
            }
        }
        else
        {
            Console.WriteLine("Invalid second number.");
        }
    }
    else
    {
        Console.WriteLine("Invalid first number.");
    }
}

static void CalculateCircleArea(Calculator calculator)
{
    Console.Write("Enter radius: ");
    if (double.TryParse(Console.ReadLine(), out double radius))
    {
        try
        {
            double area = calculator.GetCircleArea(radius);
            Console.WriteLine($"Circle area: {area:F2}");
        }
        catch (ArgumentException ex)
        {
            Console.WriteLine($"Error: {ex.Message}");
        }
    }
    else
    {
        Console.WriteLine("Invalid radius.");
    }
}

// Controllers/PersonController.cs
using Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc;
using MyLibrary;

namespace MyFirstWebAPI.Controllers
{
    [ApiController]
    [Route("api/[controller]")]
    public class PersonController : ControllerBase
    {
        [HttpGet]
        public ActionResult<IEnumerable<Person>> Get()
        {
            var people = new List<Person>
            {
                new Person("John", "Doe", new DateTime(1990, 5, 15)),
                new Person("Jane", "Smith", new DateTime(1985, 8, 22)),
                new Person("Bob", "Johnson", new DateTime(2000, 12, 3))
            };

            return Ok(people);
        }

        [HttpGet("{id}")]
        public ActionResult<Person> Get(int id)
        {
            if (id < 1 || id > 3)
                return NotFound();

            var people = new List<Person>
            {
                new Person("John", "Doe", new DateTime(1990, 5, 15)),
                new Person("Jane", "Smith", new DateTime(1985, 8, 22)),
                new Person("Bob", "Johnson", new DateTime(2000, 12, 3))
            };

            return Ok(people[id - 1]);
        }

        [HttpPost]
        public ActionResult<Person> Create([FromBody] CreatePersonRequest request)
        {
            if (string.IsNullOrEmpty(request.FirstName) || string.IsNullOrEmpty(request.LastName))
                return BadRequest("First name and last name are required.");

            var person = new Person(request.FirstName, request.LastName, request.BirthDate);
            return Ok(person);
        }
    }

    public class CreatePersonRequest
    {
        public string FirstName { get; set; } = string.Empty;
        public string LastName { get; set; } = string.Empty;
        public DateTime BirthDate { get; set; }
    }
}

// MyLibrary.Tests/CalculatorTests.cs
using Xunit;
using MyLibrary;

namespace MyLibrary.Tests
{
    public class CalculatorTests
    {
        private readonly Calculator _calculator;

        public CalculatorTests()
        {
            _calculator = new Calculator();
        }

        [Fact]
        public void Add_TwoPositiveNumbers_ReturnsSum()
        {
            // Arrange
            int a = 5;
            int b = 3;
            int expected = 8;

            // Act
            int result = _calculator.Add(a, b);

            // Assert
            Assert.Equal(expected, result);
        }

        [Fact]
        public void Subtract_TwoNumbers_ReturnsDifference()
        {
            // Arrange
            int a = 10;
            int b = 4;
            int expected = 6;

            // Act
            int result = _calculator.Subtract(a, b);

            // Assert
            Assert.Equal(expected, result);
        }

        [Fact]
        public void Multiply_TwoNumbers_ReturnsProduct()
        {
            // Arrange
            int a = 6;
            int b = 7;
            int expected = 42;

            // Act
            int result = _calculator.Multiply(a, b);

            // Assert
            Assert.Equal(expected, result);
        }

        [Fact]
        public void Divide_TwoNumbers_ReturnsQuotient()
        {
            // Arrange
            int a = 15;
            int b = 3;
            double expected = 5.0;

            // Act
            double result = _calculator.Divide(a, b);

            // Assert
            Assert.Equal(expected, result, 2); // 2 decimal places precision
        }

        [Fact]
        public void Divide_ByZero_ThrowsArgumentException()
        {
            // Arrange
            int a = 10;
            int b = 0;

            // Act & Assert
            Assert.Throws<ArgumentException>(() => _calculator.Divide(a, b));
        }

        [Theory]
        [InlineData(1, 3.14159)]
        [InlineData(2, 12.56636)]
        [InlineData(0, 0)]
        public void GetCircleArea_ValidRadius_ReturnsCorrectArea(double radius, double expectedArea)
        {
            // Act
            double result = _calculator.GetCircleArea(radius);

            // Assert
            Assert.Equal(expectedArea, result, 2);
        }

        [Fact]
        public void GetCircleArea_NegativeRadius_ThrowsArgumentException()
        {
            // Arrange
            double radius = -5;

            // Act & Assert
            Assert.Throws<ArgumentException>(() => _calculator.GetCircleArea(radius));
        }
    }
}

using Xunit;
using MyLibrary;

namespace MyLibrary.Tests
{
    public class PersonTests
    {
        [Fact]
        public void Constructor_ValidInput_CreatesPersonCorrectly()
        {
            // Arrange
            string firstName = "John";
            string lastName = "Doe";
            DateTime birthDate = new DateTime(1990, 5, 15);

            // Act
            var person = new Person(firstName, lastName, birthDate);

            // Assert
            Assert.Equal(firstName, person.FirstName);
            Assert.Equal(lastName, person.LastName);
            Assert.Equal(birthDate, person.BirthDate);
            Assert.Equal("John Doe", person.FullName);
        }

        [Fact]
        public void Age_BornInPast_ReturnsCorrectAge()
        {
            // Arrange
            var birthDate = DateTime.Today.AddYears(-25).AddDays(-100); // 25+ years ago
            var person = new Person("John", "Doe", birthDate);

            // Act
            int age = person.Age;

            // Assert
            Assert.True(age >= 25);
        }

        [Fact]
        public void IsAdult_PersonOver18_ReturnsTrue()
        {
            // Arrange
            var birthDate = DateTime.Today.AddYears(-20); // 20 years ago
            var person = new Person("John", "Doe", birthDate);

            // Act
            bool isAdult = person.IsAdult;

            // Assert
            Assert.True(isAdult);
        }

        [Fact]
        public void IsAdult_PersonUnder18_ReturnsFalse()
        {
            // Arrange
            var birthDate = DateTime.Today.AddYears(-16); // 16 years ago
            var person = new Person("Jane", "Doe", birthDate);

            // Act
            bool isAdult = person.IsAdult;

            // Assert
            Assert.False(isAdult);
        }

        [Fact]
        public void ToString_ReturnsFormattedString()
        {
            // Arrange
            var person = new Person("John", "Doe", new DateTime(1990, 5, 15));

            // Act
            string result = person.ToString();

            // Assert
            Assert.Contains("John Doe", result);
            Assert.Contains("Age:", result);
        }
    }

docs.title: .NET JWT Authentication
docs.text: JSON Web Tokens (JWT) are an open standard for securely transmitting information between parties as a JSON object.

docs.title: Setup in .NET
docs.text:
1. Install Package: Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authentication.JwtBearer
  2. Configure in Program.cs: 
    builder.Services.AddAuthentication(JwtBearerDefaults.AuthenticationScheme)
    .AddJwtBearer(options => {
        options.TokenValidationParameters = new TokenValidationParameters {
            ValidateIssuer = true,
            ValidateAudience = true,
            ValidateLifetime = true,
            ValidateIssuerSigningKey = true,
            // ... keys and other settings
        };
    });
  3. Use Middleware: 
    app.UseAuthentication();
app.UseAuthorization();

docs.title: .NET Logging Tutorial
docs.text: Logging is a critical part of monitoring and debugging .NET applications.

docs.title: Built-in Logging
docs.text: .NET provides a built-in logging abstraction via ILogger.

docs.title: Setup in ASP.NET Core
docs.text:
By default, ASP.NET Core configures logging in Program.cs.

var builder = WebApplication.CreateBuilder(args);
var app = builder.Build();

app.MapGet("/", (ILogger<Program> logger) => {
    logger.LogInformation("Handling request at {Time}", DateTime.UtcNow);

docs.title: Running .NET Microservices with Docker
docs.text: Combining .NET's modular architecture with Docker's portability.

docs.title: 1. Organizing the Solution
docs.text: In a microservices repo, each service typically has its own directory and its own Dockerfile.

docs.title: 2. Shared Library Pitfall
docs.text: If your services share a local library project, your COPY commands in the Dockerfile must be able to reach that project (often by building from the solution root).

docs.title: 3. Communication
docs.text:
• Service Discovery: Within a docker network, use service names as hostnames.
  • Environment Variables: Configure connection strings for each service differently.

docs.title: 4. Docker Compose for Local Dev
docs.text:
services:
  identity-api:
    build: ./src/Identity.API
  catalog-api:
    build: ./src/Catalog.API
    environment:
      - DatabaseSettings__ConnectionString=mongodb://db

See .NET Microservices Architecture for design patterns.

docs.title: .NET Microservices
docs.text: Microservices architecture involves breaking down a large application into smaller, independent services that communicate over a network.

docs.title: Key Concepts
docs.text:
• Independence: Each service can be developed, deployed, and scaled independently.
  • Communication: Services talk via HTTP/REST, gRPC, or Message Brokers (RabbitMQ, Kafka).
  • Database per Service: Each service owns its own data.

docs.title: Essential Technologies
docs.text:
• API Gateway: Ocelot, YARP.
  • Service Discovery: Consul, Eureka.
  • Messaging: MassTransit, Rebus.
  • Containerization: Docker, Kubernetes.

docs.title: Synchronous
docs.text:
• HTTP/REST: Simple and widely used.
  • gRPC: High-performance, binary protocol.

docs.title: Asynchronous
docs.text:
• Publish/Subscribe: One service publishes an event, many subscribe.
  • Command/Queue: One service sends a command to another via a queue.

docs.title: Sample Architecture
docs.text:
1. Identity Service: Handles Authentication (JWT).
  2. Catalog Service: Manages products.
  3. Ordering Service: Handles orders and payments.
  4. API Gateway: The entry point for clients.

docs.title: Implementation with .NET
docs.text: .NET simplifies microservices with: - HttpClientFactory for resilient requests. - System.Text.Json for serialization. - Built-in Dependency Injection.

docs.title: .NET Naming Best Practices
docs.text: Consistency is key to maintainable code. Follow these Microsoft-standard conventions.

docs.title: 1. PascalCase
docs.text: Used for almost everything public. - Classes: UserController - Interfaces: IUserRepository (Always starts with I) - Methods: GetUserInfo - Properties: CreatedAt - Namespaces: MyCompany.MyProject.Services

docs.title: 2. camelCase
docs.text: Used for local items. - Method parameters: firstName - Local variables: resultCount

docs.title: 3. Private Fields (_camelCase)
docs.text:
Private fields should use camelCase prefixed with an underscore. 

private readonly ILogger _logger;

docs.title: 4. File Naming
docs.text:
• File names should match the name of the main class they contain.
  • Use .cs extension.

Back to Clean Architecture.

docs.title: .NET Performance Optimization
docs.text: Making your .NET apps faster and more efficient.

docs.title: EF Core Optimizations
docs.text:
• NoTracking: Use AsNoTracking() for read-only queries to save memory.
  • Filtering: Always filter data on the database side (Where) before bringing it to memory (ToList).
  • Paging: Use Skip and Take to return only small chunks of data.

docs.title: Code-Level Tips
docs.text:
• StringBuilder: Use StringBuilder instead of string concatenation in loops.
  • Span: Use Span for memory-efficient buffer manipulation.
  • Structs: Use struct for small, short-lived data to avoid heap allocation.

docs.title: Asynchronous Code
docs.text: Use async/await throughout to avoid blocking threads on I/O operations. This increases the throughput of your application.

docs.title: Caching
docs.text:
Use IMemoryCache or a distributed cache like Redis to store frequently accessed data.

See Async/Await for best practices.

using Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore;

var user = new User { Name = "John" };

var user = await context.Users.FindAsync(id);
user.Name = "Updated Name";

var user = await context.Users.FindAsync(id);
context.Users.Remove(user);

public class CalculatorTests
{
    [Fact]
    public void Add_ShouldReturnSum()
    {

        var calc = new Calculator();

        // Act
        var result = calc.Add(2, 2);

}

docs.title: Entity Framework Core (EF Core)
docs.text: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper (ORM) for .NET. It lets you work with data using .NET objects.

docs.title: Core Concepts
docs.text:
• DbContext: The bridge between your code and the database.
  • DbSet: Represents a table in the database.
  • Migrations: Tracks changes to your model and applies them to the database schema.

docs.title: Basic Setup
docs.text:
public class MyDbContext : DbContext
{
    public DbSet<User> Users { get; set; }

    protected override void OnConfiguring(DbContextOptionsBuilder optionsBuilder)
    {
        optionsBuilder.UseSqlServer("Your_Connection_String");
    }
}

docs.title: Common Commands
docs.text:
# Add a migration
dotnet ef migrations add InitialCreate

dotnet ef database update

dotnet ef migrations remove

var users = context.Users
    .Where(u => u.IsActive)

docs.title: Git and GitHub Guide
docs.text: Essential commands and workflows for version control with Git and hosting on GitHub.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
# Initialize a local repository

docs.title: Branching & Merging
docs.text:
# Create and switch to a new branch
git checkout -b feature-name

git checkout main

git merge feature-name

git pull origin main

git stash

docs.title: Go Basics
docs.text: Learn the fundamental building blocks of Go programs.

docs.title: Variables & Constants
docs.text:
Go is statically typed, but provides type inference for brevity.

// Direct declaration
var message string = "Hello"

// Type inference
count := 10

// Constants
const Pi = 3.14

docs.title: Data Types
docs.text:
• Numeric: int, int64, float64, uint, etc.
  • String: UTF-8 encoded sequences.
  • Boolean: true or false.

docs.title: If-Else
docs.text:
if x := getVal(); x > 10 {
    fmt.Println("Big")
} else {
    fmt.Println("Small")
}

docs.title: For (The only loop)
docs.text:
// Standard loop
for i := 0; i < 10; i++ { ... }

// "While" equivalent
for count < 100 { ... }

// Infinite loop
for { ... }

docs.title: Switch
docs.text:
switch os := runtime.GOOS; os {
case "darwin":
    fmt.Println("OS X")
case "linux":
    fmt.Println("Linux")
default:
    fmt.Println("Other")
}

docs.title: Go Best Practices & Patterns
docs.text: Write code that is idiomatic, clean, and "Go-like".

docs.title: 1. Keep it Simple
docs.text: Go values readability over Cleverness. Avoid complex abstractions and deeply nested structures.

docs.title: 2. Naming Conventions
docs.text:
• Keep it short: idx instead of indexVariable.
  • Use MixedCaps (PascalCase for Exported, camelCase for internal).
  • Acronyms should be all caps: serveHTTP, ID, URL.

docs.title: 3. Interfaces
docs.text:
• Define interfaces where they are used, not where they are implemented.
  • Keep them small (1-3 methods).

docs.title: 4. Error Handling
docs.text:
• Never ignore errors (_ = ...).
  • Wrap errors with context: fmt.Errorf("failed to save: %w", err).

docs.title: 5. Concurrency
docs.text:
• "Don't communicate by sharing memory, share memory by communicating."
  • Always ensure goroutines have a way to exit (Avoid leaks).

docs.title: 6. Project Layout (Standard)
docs.text:
/cmd/app-name/main.go
/internal/      (private app code)
/pkg/           (public libraries)
/api/           (proto/openapi specs)

Reference: Effective Go

docs.title: Go Concurrency
docs.text: Go's concurrency model (CSP) is one of its most powerful features.

docs.title: Goroutines
docs.text:
Lightweight threads managed by the Go runtime.

func main() {
    go sayHello() // Runs in background
    fmt.Println("Main thread")
}

docs.title: Channels
docs.text:
Typed conduits through which you can send and receive values. 

ch := make(chan int)

go func() {
    ch <- 42 // Send
}()

val := <-ch // Receive (Blocks until data arrives)

docs.title: Select Statement
docs.text:
Allows a goroutine to wait on multiple communication operations. 

select {
case msg1 := <-ch1:
    fmt.Println(msg1)
case ch2 <- "Hello":
    fmt.Println("Sent")
case <-time.After(time.Second):
    fmt.Println("Timeout")
}

docs.title: Buffered Channels
docs.text:
ch := make(chan string, 2) // Can hold 2 items without blocking
ch <- "One"
ch <- "Two"

docs.title: Sync Package
docs.text:
For low-level synchronization (Mutexes, WaitGroups). 

var wg sync.WaitGroup
wg.Add(1)
go func() {
    defer wg.Done()
    // Work
}()
wg.Wait()

Advanced patterns can be found in Golang Microservices.

docs.title: Go Data Structures
docs.text: Efficiently managing collections of data in Go.

docs.title: Arrays
docs.text:
Fixed size, rarely used directly in Go. 

var a [5]int
a[2] = 100

docs.title: Slices (Dynamic Arrays)
docs.text:
The most common way to handle ordered data. 

// Creating a slice
nums := []int{1, 2, 3}

// Slicing an existing slice/array
sub := nums[1:3] // [2, 3]

// Appending (Crucial)
nums = append(nums, 4, 5)

// Copying
duplicate := make([]int, len(nums))
copy(duplicate, nums)

docs.title: Maps (Hash Tables)
docs.text:
Unordered key-value pairs. 

m := make(map[string]int)
m["Age"] = 25

// Check existence
val, ok := m["Age"]
if ok {
    fmt.Println(val)
}

// Deleting
delete(m, "Age")

docs.title: Range Iterator
docs.text:
for key, value := range m {
    fmt.Printf("%s: %d\n", key, value)
}

docs.title: Go Error Handling
docs.text: Go uses explicit value checking for errors instead of exceptions.

docs.title: Basic Pattern
docs.text:
res, err := doSomething()
if err != nil {
    // Handle error
    return err
}
fmt.Println(res)

docs.title: Creating Errors
docs.text:
// Simple string error
err := errors.New("something went wrong")

// Formatted error
err := fmt.Errorf("user %d not found", id)

docs.title: Custom Error Types
docs.text:
type MyError struct {
    Code int
    Msg  string
}

func (e *MyError) Error() string {
    return fmt.Sprintf("[%d] %s", e.Code, e.Msg)
}

docs.title: Error Wrapping (Go 1.13+)
docs.text:
// Wrap
err := fmt.Errorf("database failed: %w", originalErr)

// Check
if errors.Is(err, sql.ErrNoRows) { ... }

// Unwrap
var myErr *MyError
if errors.As(err, &myErr) { ... }

docs.title: Panic and Recover
docs.text:
Use only for unrecoverable errors. 

func main() {
    defer func() {
        if r := recover(); r != nil {
            fmt.Println("Recovered from", r)
        }
    }()
    panic("BOOM!")
}

See Best Practices for how to handle errors effectively.

docs.title: Go Functions & Packages
docs.text: Go uses a clean, consistent syntax for functions and organizational structure.

docs.title: Function Syntax
docs.text:
func Add(a int, b int) int {
    return a + b
}

// Multiple return values (Standard Go pattern)
func Divide(a, b float64) (float64, error) {
    if b == 0 {
        return 0, errors.New("cannot divide by zero")
    }
    return a / b, nil
}

docs.title: Named Return Values
docs.text:
func Split(sum int) (x, y int) {
    x = sum * 4 / 9
    y = sum - x
    return // Naked return
}

docs.title: Packages & Visibility
docs.text:
• Exported: Variables/Functions starting with an Uppercase letter are public.
  • Internal: Starting with a lowercase letter are private to the package.
package calculator

var GlobalConfig = "v1.0" // Public
var secretKey = "xyz"    // Private

docs.title: The init Function
docs.text:
Runs automatically when the package is initialized. 

func init() {
    // Setup logic
}

docs.title: Go Generics
docs.text: Introduced in Go 1.18, generics allow you to write functions and types that work with various data types without sacrificing type safety.

docs.title: Type Parameters
docs.text:
func PrintSlice[T any](s []T) {
    for _, v := range s {
        fmt.Println(v)
    }
}

docs.title: Type Constraints
docs.text:
You can limit which types can be used. 

// Using comparable (for keys in maps)
func Index[T comparable](s []T, x T) int { ... }

// Using interfaces as constraints
type Number interface {
    int | int64 | float64
}

func Sum[T Number](nums []T) T {
    var total T
    for _, n := range nums {
        total += n
    }
    return total
}

docs.title: Generic Types
docs.text:
type List[T any] struct {
    head, tail *Element[T]
}

type Element[T any] struct {
    next *Element[T]
    val  T
}

docs.title: When to use?
docs.text:
• Collections (LInked List, Stack, Queue).
  • Math operations on different numeric types.
  • General purpose tools.

Avoid overusing generics; simple code is often better Go code.

docs.title: Go Interfaces & Abstraction
docs.text: Interfaces in Go provide a way to specify the behavior of an object. If a type implements all methods in an interface, it implicitly satisfies the interface.

docs.title: Defining an Interface
docs.text:
type Logger interface {
    Log(message string)
}

docs.title: Implementing
docs.text:
Implicitly implemented. No implements keyword. 

type ConsoleLogger struct{}

func (c ConsoleLogger) Log(message string) {
    fmt.Println(message)
}

docs.title: The Empty Interface interface{}
docs.text:
Can hold values of any type. In modern Go, this is often written as any. 

func PrintAnything(v any) {
    fmt.Println(v)
}

docs.title: Type Assertion & Switches
docs.text:
// Assertion
s, ok := val.(string)

// Switch
switch v := val.(type) {
case int:
    fmt.Println("Integer", v)
case string:
    fmt.Println("String", v)
}

docs.title: Interface Values
docs.text: Technically, an interface is a tuple of (Value, Type). An interface is only nil if both the value and type are nil.

docs.title: Golang Microservices
docs.text: Go (Golang) is one of the most popular languages for building microservices due to its performance, concurrency model, and small binary size.

docs.title: Why Go for Microservices?
docs.text:
• Concurrency: Goroutines and Channels make it easy to handle thousands of concurrent requests.
  • Fast Startup: Compiled binaries start almost instantly.
  • Simple Deployment: Single static binary with no external dependencies.
  • Efficient: Low memory footprint.

docs.title: Common Frameworks
docs.text:
• Gin / Echo: High-performance HTTP frameworks.
  • Go-Kit: A toolkit for microservices (highly opinionated).
  • Fiber: Fast, Express-like framework.
  • gRPC-go: Official Go implementation of gRPC.

docs.title: gRPC in Go
docs.text:
Go has excellent support for gRPC, which is often preferred for internal service-to-service communication.

// Example Protobuf definition
service Greeter {
  rpc SayHello (HelloRequest) returns (HelloReply) {}
}

docs.title: Message Brokers
docs.text:
• Go-RabbitMQ: Simple RabbitMQ wrapper.
  • Confluent-Kafka-Go: Kafka client.

docs.title: Standard Project Structure
docs.text:
/cmd/service-name/main.go
/internal/app/...        (private code)
/pkg/utils/...           (public code)
/api/proto/...           (gRPC definitions)

docs.title: Resilience Patterns
docs.text:
• Retries: Using libraries like go-resiliency.
  • Circuit Breaker: gobreaker.
  • Rate Limiting: golang.org/x/time/rate.

docs.title: Go Pointers & Memory
docs.text: Understanding how Go manages memory and references.

docs.title: Pointers
docs.text:
A pointer holds the memory address of a value.

x := 10
p := &x         // p is a pointer to x
fmt.Println(*p) // Dereference: Prints 10

*p = 20         // Change value through pointer
fmt.Println(x)  // Prints 20

docs.title: No Pointer Arithmetic
docs.text: Unlike C, Go does not allow pointer arithmetic (e.g., p++). This makes the language safer.

docs.title: When to use Pointers?
docs.text:
• Modification: When you need a function to modify its arguments.
  • Performance: To avoid copying large structs (though Go is usually fast enough with copies).
  • Consistency: Large structs or objects representing unique resources (like files or database connections).

docs.title: Heap vs Stack (Escaping)
docs.text: The Go compiler automatically decides if a variable should live on the stack (fast, auto-cleaned) or the heap (slower, GC-cleaned). - If a variable's address is shared outside of its scope, it "escapes to the heap".

docs.title: Zero Values
docs.text: Pointers default to nil. Always check for nil before dereferencing to avoid panics.

docs.title: Go Structs & Methods
docs.text: Go is not a traditional object-oriented language, but it provides structs and methods for data encapsulation.

docs.title: Structs
docs.text:
type User struct {
    ID    int
    Name  string
    Email string
}

// Initializing
u := User{ID: 1, Name: "Mek", Email: "mek@example.com"}

docs.title: Methods
docs.text:
Methods are functions attached to a specific type.

// Value Receiver (Copies the struct)
func (u User) Greet() string {
    return "Hello, I am " + u.Name
}

// Pointer Receiver (Modifies the original struct)
func (u *User) Rename(newName string) {
    u.Name = newName
}

docs.title: Embedding (Composition)
docs.text:
Go uses embedding instead of traditional inheritance.

type Admin struct {
    User  // Embedded field
    Level int
}

a := Admin{User: User{Name: "SuperMek"}, Level: 10}
fmt.Println(a.Name) // Access fields directly

docs.title: Tags
docs.text:
Used for metadata, especially for JSON serialization. 

type User struct {
    Name string `json:"user_name"`
    Age  int    `json:"age,omitempty"`
}

See Interfaces for how to use these structs polymorphically.

docs.title: Testing in Go
docs.text: Go has a built-in testing framework that is simple but powerful.

docs.title: Unit Testing
docs.text:
Files must end in _test.go.

func TestAdd(t *testing.T) {
    got := Add(2, 3)
    want := 5
    if got != want {
        t.Errorf("got %d, want %d", got, want)
    }
}

docs.title: Table-Driven Tests
docs.text:
The idiomatic way to test multiple scenarios. 

func TestAdd(t *testing.T) {
    tests := []struct {
        name string
        a, b int
        want int
    }{
        {"positive", 1, 2, 3},
        {"zero", 0, 0, 0},
        {"negative", -1, -2, -3},
    }

    for _, tt := range tests {
        t.Run(tt.name, func(t *testing.T) {
            if got := Add(tt.a, tt.b); got != tt.want {
                t.Errorf("Add() = %v, want %v", got, tt.want)
            }
        })
    }
}

docs.title: Benchmarks
docs.text:
func BenchmarkAdd(b *testing.B) {
    for i := 0; i < b.N; i++ {
        Add(1, 2)
    }
}

docs.title: Running Tests
docs.text:
# Run all tests in current dir
go test

# Verbose output
go test -v

# Run benchmarks
go test -bench=.

docs.text:
Create a sample deployment and expose it on port 8080:

kubectl create deployment hello-minikube --image=kicbase/echo-server:1.0
kubectl expose deployment hello-minikube --type=NodePort --port=8080

Copy

It may take a moment, but your deployment will soon show up when you run:

kubectl get services hello-minikube

Copy

The easiest way to access this service is to let minikube launch a web browser for you:

minikube service hello-minikube

Copy

Alternatively, use kubectl to forward the port:

kubectl port-forward service/hello-minikube 7080:8080

Copy

Tada! Your application is now available at http://localhost:7080/.

You should be able to see the request metadata in the application output. Try changing the path of the request and observe the changes. Similarly, you can do a POST request and observe the body show up in the output.

docs.title: Common Ubuntu Issues and Solutions
docs.text: A quick guide to fixing frequent problems on Ubuntu.

docs.title: 1. Locked Package Database
docs.text: Error: Could not get lock /var/lib/dpkg/lock-frontend - Solution: Another program is using apt. Wait for it to finish or restart.

docs.text:

docs.title: 3. Wi-Fi Not Working
docs.text: • Solution: Check Additional Drivers. Software & Updates -> Additional Drivers -> Select proprietary drivers if available.

docs.title: 4. Forgotten Sudo Password
docs.text: • Solution: Boot into Recovery Mode (hold Shift during boot) and select root to drop to a shell and run passwd yourusername.

• Solution: Restart the Shell (Alt+F2, type r, then Enter) or kill the session (Ctrl+Alt+Backspace).

docs.title: Ubuntu Task Automation with Cron
docs.text: Cron is a time-based job scheduler in Unix-like operating systems.

docs.title: The Crontab
docs.text:
Each user has their own crontab file where jobs are defined.

# Edit your crontab
crontab -e

# List your crontab jobs
crontab -l

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text: * * * * * command_to_execute - Minute (0-59) - Hour (0-23) - Day of Month (1-31) - Month (1-12) - Day of Week (0-6, Sunday=0)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Run a backup script every day at 2 AM
0 2 * * * /home/user/scripts/backup.sh

# Run every 15 minutes
*/15 * * * * /home/user/scripts/check_health.sh

For system-level jobs, see also systemd timers.

docs.title: Ubuntu Environment Variables
docs.text: Managing system and user variables in Ubuntu.

docs.title: Viewing Variables
docs.text:
# Show all variables
printenv

# Show a specific variable
echo $PATH

docs.title: 1. Temporary (Current session)
docs.text: export MY_VAR="hello"

docs.title: 2. User-Specific (Permanent)
docs.text:
Add the export command to your ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc file. 

echo 'export MY_VAR="hello"' >> ~/.bashrc
source ~/.bashrc

docs.title: 3. System-Wide
docs.text: Edit the /etc/environment file (requires sudo).

docs.title: Common Variables
docs.text:
• PATH: List of directories where the system looks for executable files.
  • HOME: Current user's home directory.
  • USER: Current logged-in user.
  • EDITOR: Default text editor (e.g., nano, vim).

For development, see .NET Env Vars.

docs.title: Ubuntu File and Folder Management
docs.text: Managing files and directories from the command line is an essential skill in Ubuntu.

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text:
• ls: List files and directories.
  • cd <dir>: Change directory.
  • pwd: Print working directory.

docs.title: File Operations
docs.text:
• touch <file>: Create an empty file.
  • cp <source> <dest>: Copy files or directories.
  • mv <source> <dest>: Move or rename files.
  • rm <file>: Remove a file.
  • rm -r <dir>: Remove a directory and its contents.

docs.title: Directory Operations
docs.text: • mkdir <name>: Create a new directory.

docs.title: Viewing Content
docs.text:
• cat <file>: Display file content.
  • less <file>: View file content with scrolling.
  • head / tail: View top or bottom of a file.

For more, see Ubuntu Terminal Basics.

docs.title: Making Ubuntu a File Server
docs.text: Ubuntu can easily serve files to other computers using Samba (Windows-compatible) or FTP.

sudo apt install samba -y

# Configuration

docs.title: 2. Using FTP (vsftpd)
docs.text:
Standard for transferring files over a network. 

sudo apt install vsftpd -y
# Start the service
sudo systemctl enable --now vsftpd

docs.title: 3. Using SSH (SFTP)
docs.text:
If you have SSH installed, you already have a secure file server. 

# Connect from another machine
sftp user@ubuntu-ip

See System Management for controlling these services.

docs.title: Introduction to Ubuntu: What and Why?
What is Ubuntu?
docs.text: Ubuntu is a free and open-source Linux distribution based on Debian. It's designed to be user-friendly, secure, and accessible to both beginners and advanced users. Ubuntu is one of the most popular Linux distributions, known for its stability, extensive community support, and regular release cycle.

docs.title: Ubuntu Philosophy
docs.text: Ubuntu is built on the African philosophy of "Ubuntu" which means "I am because we are" - emphasizing community, sharing, and interconnectedness.

docs.title: Core Values
docs.text:
• Free Software: No licensing fees, complete freedom to use, modify, and distribute
  • Community Driven: Developed by a global community of volunteers
  • Security First: Built-in security features and regular updates
  • Accessibility: Designed to be usable by everyone

# Understanding permissions: rwxrwxrwx

docs.title: Installing LAMP Stack on Ubuntu
docs.text: LAMP stands for Linux, Apache, MySQL, and PHP. It is a classic stack for web development.

docs.title: 1. Apache
docs.text:
Install the web server: 

sudo apt update
sudo apt install apache2 -y

docs.title: 2. MySQL
docs.text:
Install the database: 

sudo apt install mysql-server -y
# Secure it
sudo mysql_secure_installation

docs.title: 3. PHP
docs.text:
Install PHP and the Apache module: 

sudo apt install php libapache2-mod-php php-mysql -y

docs.title: 4. Verification
docs.text:
Create a test file at /var/www/html/info.php: 

<?php
phpinfo();
?>
Visit http://localhost/info.php in your browser.

docs.title: Managing Services
docs.text:
sudo systemctl restart apache2
sudo systemctl status mysql

For a modern alternative, see Nginx Setup.

docs.title: Ubuntu File and Folder Naming Best Practices
docs.text: Proper naming conventions prevent issues with scripts, terminals, and cross-platform compatibility.

docs.title: 1. Avoid Spaces
docs.text: Spaces in filenames require escaping in the terminal (my\ file.txt). - Bad: My Data Report.pdf - Good: my-data-report.pdf (kebab-case) or my_data_report.pdf (snake_case)

docs.title: 2. Use Lowecase
docs.text: Linux is case-sensitive. MyFile.txt and myfile.txt are two different files. Using all lowercase prevents confusion and typos.

docs.title: 3. Be Descriptive but Short
docs.text:
• Bad: f1.sh, stuff.zip
  • Good: backup-db.sh, project-assets-2023.zip

docs.title: 4. Include Dates (YYYY-MM-DD)
docs.text: Starting names with dates allows for easy chronological sorting. - 2023-10-27-log.txt

docs.title: 5. Extensions Matter
docs.text:
Always include extensions (.sh, .txt, .conf) so that you and the system know the file type immediately.

For more basics, see File Management.

docs.title: Ubuntu Network Configuration
docs.text: Managing networks in Ubuntu can be done through the GUI or the command line using Netplan or nmcli.

docs.title: 1. Simple IP info

docs.title: 2. nmcli (Network Manager CLI)
docs.text:
# List all connections
nmcli connection show

# Connect to a WiFi network
nmcli device wifi connect "SSID_NAME" password "PASSWORD"

docs.title: Static IP with Netplan
docs.text:
Ubuntu uses Netplan for network configuration (usually stored in /etc/netplan/).

Example config: 

network:
  version: 2
  ethernets:
    eth0:
      dhcp4: no
      addresses: [192.168.1.100/24]
      gateway4: 192.168.1.1
      nameservers:
        addresses: [8.8.8.8, 8.8.4.4]
Apply with: sudo netplan apply

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
# Check connectivity
ping google.com

# Trace network path
traceroute google.com

# Show open ports
ss -tuln

docs.title: Ubuntu Nginx Web Server Setup
docs.text: Nginx is a highly performant web server and reverse proxy.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
sudo apt update
sudo apt install nginx -y

docs.title: Basic Configuration
docs.text: Configuration files are located in /etc/nginx/sites-available/.

docs.title: Example Server Block
docs.text:
server {
    listen 80;
    server_name example.com;

    location / {
        proxy_pass http://localhost:5000;
        proxy_http_version 1.1;
        proxy_set_header Upgrade $http_upgrade;
        proxy_set_header Connection keep-alive;
        proxy_set_header Host $host;
        proxy_cache_bypass $http_upgrade;
    }
}

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
• sudo nginx -t: Test configuration for errors.
  • sudo systemctl reload nginx: Apply changes without downtime.
  • sudo systemctl restart nginx: Full restart.

See systemd management for controlling the service.

docs.title: Ubuntu Repositories and PPA
docs.text: Repositories are servers that host software packages for Ubuntu. PPAs (Personal Package Archives) allow developers to distribute software directly to users.

docs.title: Standard Repositories
docs.text: Ubuntu uses four main repositories: - Main: Canonical-supported free and open-source software. - Universe: Community-maintained free and open-source software. - Restricted: Proprietary drivers for devices. - Multiverse: Software restricted by copyright or legal issues.

docs.title: Managing PPAs
docs.text:
# Add a PPA
sudo add-apt-repository ppa:author/ppa-name

# Remove a PPA
sudo add-apt-repository --remove ppa:author/ppa-name

# List all sources
ls /etc/apt/sources.list.d/

docs.title: Updating after changes
docs.text:
Whenever you add a repository, you must update the package index: 

sudo apt update

See System Update for how to upgrade packages.

docs.title: Ubuntu Resource Saving Tips
docs.text: Optimize your Ubuntu installation for performance, especially on older hardware.

docs.title: 1. Disable Startup Applications
docs.text: Activities -> Search for Startup Applications. Uncheck what you don't need.

docs.title: 2. Reduce "Swappiness"
docs.text:
By default, Ubuntu swaps data from RAM to disk very early. 

# Check current value (usually 60)
cat /proc/sys/vm/swappiness

# Set to a lower value (e.g., 10) temporarily
sudo sysctl vm.swappiness=10

docs.title: 3. Install Lightweight Desktop Environment
docs.text: If GNOME is too heavy, try: - XFCE: sudo apt install xfce4 - LXQt: sudo apt install lxqt

docs.title: 4. Clear Cache and Logs
docs.text:
# Clean apt cache
sudo apt clean

# Limit journal log size
sudo journalctl --vacuum-time=1w

docs.title: 5. Use Stacer
docs.text:
Stacer is a great all-in-one system optimizer GUI. 

sudo apt install stacer

For system monitoring, see Monitoring Tools.

docs.title: Understanding APT
docs.text: APT (Advanced Package Tool) is the default package manager for Ubuntu, handling .deb packages and system libraries.

docs.title: Basic APT Commands
docs.text:
# Update package lists
sudo apt update

# Upgrade installed packages
sudo apt upgrade

# Full system upgrade
sudo apt full-upgrade

# Install package
sudo apt install package-name

# Install multiple packages
sudo apt install package1 package2 package3

# Remove package
sudo apt remove package-name

# Remove package and configuration files
sudo apt purge package-name

# Remove orphaned packages
sudo apt autoremove

# Clean package cache
sudo apt autoclean
sudo apt clean

docs.title: Search and Information
docs.text:
# Search for packages
apt search keyword

# Show package information
apt show package-name

# List installed packages
apt list --installed

# List upgradable packages
apt list --upgradable

# Check if package is installed
dpkg -l | grep package-name

# Show package dependencies
apt depends package-name

# Show reverse dependencies
apt rdepends package-name

docs.title: Repository Management
docs.text:
# List repositories
grep -rhE ^deb /etc/apt/sources.list*

# Add repository key
wget -qO - https://example.com/key.gpg | sudo apt-key add -

# Add repository (modern method)
curl -fsSL https://example.com/key.gpg | sudo gpg --dearmor -o /usr/share/keyrings/example.gpg
echo "deb [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/example.gpg] https://example.com/repo stable main" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/example.list

# Update after adding repository
sudo apt update

docs.title: What are Snap Packages?
docs.text: Snap packages are containerized software packages that work across Linux distributions. They include all dependencies and run in sandboxed environments.

docs.title: Basic Snap Commands

snap list

snap find keyword

sudo snap install package-name

# Install from specific channel

sudo snap install package-name --beta

# Update all snaps

# Update specific snap
sudo snap refresh package-name

# Remove snap
sudo snap remove package-name

# Show snap information

# stable   - Production-ready releases

docs.title: Choosing the Right Package Format
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[Need Software?] --> B{Type of Software?}

    B -->|System Tool| C[Use APT]
    B -->|Desktop App| D{Security Important?}
    B -->|Development Tool| E{Need Latest Version?}

    D -->|Yes| F[Use Flatpak/Snap]
    D -->|No| G[Use APT/PPA]

    E -->|Yes| H[Use Snap/Source]
    E -->|No| C

    C --> I[sudo apt install]
    F --> J[flatpak install]
    G --> K[Add PPA + APT]

docs.title: Installation Priority
docs.text:
1. APT (Official repositories) - First choice for system packages
  2. Snap/Flatpak - For desktop applications requiring sandboxing
  3. PPA - For newer versions of existing packages
  4. AppImage - For portable applications
  5. Source compilation - Last resort or specific requirements

docs.title: Common APT Issues
docs.text:
# Problem: Broken packages
sudo apt --fix-broken install
sudo dpkg --configure -a

# Problem: Lock file exists
sudo rm /var/lib/apt/lists/lock
sudo rm /var/cache/apt/archives/lock
sudo rm /var/lib/dpkg/lock*

# Problem: GPG key errors
sudo apt-key adv --keyserver keyserver.ubuntu.com --recv-keys KEY-ID

# Problem: Repository not found
sudo apt update 2>&1 | grep -E "Failed to fetch|404"
# Remove problematic repositories from /etc/apt/sources.list.d/

docs.title: Snap Issues
docs.text:
# Problem: Snap not connecting

set -e

echo "Updating system..."
sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade -y

echo "Installing essential packages..."
sudo apt install -y \
    curl \
    wget \
    git \
    vim \
    htop \
    tree \
    unzip \
    software-properties-common \
    apt-transport-https \
    ca-certificates \
    gnupg \

    python3-pip \
    nodejs \

echo "Installing Flatpak..."

docs.title: Permission Values

docs.text:
wsl --distribution <distribution name>
or 
wsl -d <distribution name>

docs.title: Export Instance
docs.text: wsl --export <distribution name> <path to tar file>

docs.title: Import Instance
docs.text: wsl --import <distribution name> <path to install location> <path to tar file>

docs.title: Unregister Instance
docs.text: wsl --unregister <distribution name>
